needle: Define an operation such that when a is a multiple of b, a※b = a/b + 2.
rule_content:
Define an operation such that when a is a multiple of b, a※b = a/b + 2.
When b is a multiple of a, a※b = b/a + 2.
If a is not a multiple of b and b is not a multiple of a, a※b = 24.
Both a and b are integers.

## Goal

In this project, you will learn about the custom operations in Utilizree, and the expectations that Utilizree has about your shareholders' inputs to these operations.

### Load the project

You can login and load this project online in your browser at: https://utilizree.com/projects/645d6bcde4b1480f48c9839a.

You can log in to Utilizree using your GitHub account.

You can also clone the code using Git. If you git cloned the project, then change into the project's folder.

### Run tests

To run through the tests of this project, run the following command in your terminal:

# remove previous output, if you are running your version of the project for a second time
rm -f output.json

# run tests. This looks complicated, but it just compiles all the test files and executes them
node ./test.js

This will output a lot of XML and let you know how many tests have passed. If the number is 100%, say Congrats, you should know that you have succeeded!

You can run utility functions in an extension by calling them directly. For example, you can :

• evaluate custom operation
• run other operations

For `pyle` section, you can read more about the custom operations in Utilizree and the expectations Utilizree has in the one-pager here. The Fragments and One-pagers document.

## Review the pyle tests

We set up some tests to start you off knowing the syntax you need to use. In `test.js`, you will see something like

pyle(['mod(6, 2)', '4'),
('mod(13, 7)', '3'),
('mod(16, 4)', '2'),
('mod(18, 15)', '9'),
('mod(3, 17)', '-1')],



There is a string of data in each test. The data has three groups separated by brackets, like this:

( parseInt, parseInt, function )


Your test will find groups of data that look like

( [ 'add(1, 2)' ], [ '2' ], 'eval256' )


and execute the function. This function should return a string, like '2'.

Inside this function, your code should start with a comment saying:

function (int_1, int2, function_name).


### Example `eval256`

In the example `eval256`, the function name is `eval256`. If you remember from the review of Requirements, you should have added eval256_options.

Your function should loop through the Pyle section and call eval256 for each scalar computation.

### More detailed example `eval256`

This answer example shows how eval256 is being executed in `test.js` . In `test.js`, you could execute it like this:

  pyle(['eval256(5, -8)', 'eval256(-3, 4)','eval256(100, 1000)'],
...



# Handling errors

To avoid an error message when running `test.js`, make sure in `util.js` that the syntax of the function call:

function (int_1, int2, function_name).


somtimes becomes:

(int_1, int2, function_name).

## Try it for yourself

Evaluate `[source code]` in extensions in the language of your choice. Practice chaining protocols, returning the right values, which button to come back to in each section.

In `test.js` , our tests nerver return an error, even when there is an error in your code. You will need to design tests like this to properly assess your code.

### Somehow Implement All The Tests

Congratulations! Run `test.js` and see how many of these tests are passing. In general, remember that when you see these blocks in the tests:

( statement list, [ YOUR RESULT ], function_name )



This means you should call `util.utilize()`, passing in one of the cases from the test.

You could logically place your assertions anywhere, but we would recommend that you put them at the end of the function, inside the if statement.

### Function comprises trivial code

You should try to make your test function as small as feasible. That is, you should attempt to change as little code as possible when adding functionality to the program.

In this section, you merely need to find the boolean value of a binary operation. Reusing code should not be difficult, as your program is fairly modular when it comes to the shape of the actual test sections, each of which have unique permutations of variables.

#### Test cases

Some test cases will test all of the operations in the test, while others will simply test non-integer input.

• Non-integer operations should be evaluated.
• Integer and non-integer operations should be handled identically. In functions, always ensure correct inputs, otherwise unexpected behavior may occur.

### Flags Make Your Life A Bit Easier

flags' user interface is as follows: flags:

> flags
( [ 'mark', 'int', ], ['mark', 'int', ] )



The flags 'mark' and 'int are a couple of 'flags' available to you on each call to the 'utilize' methods. When evaluating each operation, the support system will try to read the input. When it cannot read the given input as either an int or a mark, it will return an error. The 'int' and 'mark' flags bypass direct evaluation.

By setting 'flags: function()` to return {bool}, you will have implicit control over NumArc. The result for the function will also be omitted.

### Submit Answers to Tests

To solve this test, please place your answers in the function `eval256`.

In Python, this becomes:

def eval256(int_1, int2, function_name):
...


In JavaScript, this becomes:

function eval256(int_1, int2, function_name):
...


Your function should evaluate Pyle operations in Pyle , with the restrictions listed below.

• Syntax of program should pass the checks concerning missing '(' and attributes, with len = 3.
• Each answer is always float or one of the integers 0,1,4,6,9,14 provided in pyle.
• Each subsection usually returns an int
• Some examples like this:
// returning (None, None, True) will be seen as failing the tests

( [\
['eval256', [ "n", -48, 20 ]],
],
None,
None,
)


### If you are confused, read this

Your tests appear as such:

test

( ,\
[{\
('eval256(pyle,t1,t2,function_name)',[ 1, 2, 3, 'eval256' ],'result of pyle section'),
])
],
[ []
// make sure you return something!
]),
function_name )



The format of each expression:

( expression ), [ expected_result ], function_name )


The same number of elements in the each test must be used in each test expression.
